result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.descr: Demand for Discovery and Inspection - Prosecutor

records.addlTxt: 2:54 PM Called 22CF171 for PH.  Defendant Brady M Hughes-Lepinski in court.  Attorney Daniel James Chapman in court for Brady M Hughes-Lepinski.  Prosecuting attorney Kevin Thomas Schmidt in court for the State of Wisconsin. All appear in person. Case is on for preliminary hearing.  State calls first witness, C.S., who is sworn in and testifies. Stipulate to training and experience of C.S. Objection, relevance. Sustained.  State continues questioning witness.  Attny Chapman cross examines the witness. Objection speculation.  Overruled. Attny Chapman restates question. No further questions.  State redirects. Objection, relevance. Sustained. State has no further questions. No re-cross.  Witness has identified the defendant.  Venue is made.  Court finds probable cause that a crime has been committed and the defendant probably committed it.  The matter is bound over for further proceedings.  The State files information.  Arraignment scheduled for October 6, 2022 at 10:45 am.
